text: CipherTrace makes it easy for exchanges and crypto businesses to comply with cryptocurrency anti money laundering laws, avoid illegal sources of funds, and maintain healthy banking relationships. Cypher Trace is helping you grow the crypto economy by keeping it safe and secure.
speaker: B

text: Today's guest is Tushar Jain, partner at Multicoin Capital. Welcome, Tushar.
speaker: A

text: Hi, Laura. It's great to be on in Disclosure.
speaker: C

text: Before we dive into today's discussion, multicoin Capital has invested in BNB Tokens, and the reason that's relevant is because we're going to talk about what happened with finance this week, the hack of slightly more than 7000 bitcoins, roughly $40 million at the time. What do we know about what happened?
speaker: A

text: So we know a few things, and finance has been very transparent, actually, about the hack. This was a very sophisticated attack. This was not a simple hack. This was probably something that the attackers were working on for weeks, if not months. And they were able to compromise a large number of user accounts. Then they used that access to basically submit a transaction from Binance's hot wallet to a wallet controlled by the hacker. And as Binance disclosed, it was clear that the attacker had really good knowledge about the alerts and the risk management systems and the risk control systems that Binance has in place. So they were basically able to thread the needle, for lack of a better analogy, and they were able to clean out the entire Bitcoin hot wallet that Binance had, which was just over 7000 bitcoin.
speaker: C

text: Yeah. And just to quote from the notice or the blog post that they published, they said that hackers were able to obtain a large number of user API keys, two FA codes, the two factor codes that get sent to your phone or are on an app that you use, and potentially other info. And they say that the hackers used a variety of techniques, including phishing, viruses and other attacks. And Binance said that they're still figuring out all the different methods that were used, and also that there might even be more accounts that haven't been identified. I think what's interesting about it is when we had that and it's still going on, the epidemic of the phone numbers that were being hijacked, when one happens at any given time, you don't think about that exchange being hacked because it just feels like that user is being hacked. Right, but it's only because these were all coordinated, that it really felt like an attack on Binance. But one other thing that I wasn't sure about was so if you were to try something like that, I know with Coinbase that they have their vault where a user can store their money in the hot wallet or in cold search. But for this situation, I looked at a bunch of those transactions that were part of the hack, and some of them, they're large. It's like 450 bitcoin, 360 bitcoin, stuff like that. So does that mean that those individual users were keeping that amount of bitcoin in their own hot wallet on finance?
speaker: A

text: As far as I am aware, finance does not give users the ability to decide what percentage of their funds are held in cold storage versus hot wallets. I think they decide that at an exchange level, and they basically refill hot wallets if they get depleted from their cold storage. And so I don't know if that abstraction of the user put their coins into cold storage versus hot storage makes a big difference, because at the end of the day, the exchange is responsible for the hack. Right. And as we saw in this case, binance is making sure that no users are actually losing any money at all and they're covering the entire cost of the hack. I would expect that to happen for any reputable exchange in this space. If they can afford to cover the loss, it is their responsibility to cover that loss.
speaker: C

text: Yeah, and I think that was a policy they put in place after a previous hack, I guess. And then I did see that, actually, I'm forgetting who it was, but somebody in the block published something saying that they estimated that if the revenues were similar to quarter one, then they would recoup the money lost within like 47 days anyway. Well, okay, so the bigger issue actually ended up kind of occurring after the hack, in a way, a bitcoin. Core developer Jeremy Rubin very casually, actually, which I found interesting. Tweeted to CZ, who's the CEO of Binance, that the company could basically incentivize miners to reorg the chain so as to basically kind of recoup the hacked coins. And what he tweeted was CZ or CZ binance, which is CZ's Twitter handle. If you reveal your private keys for the hacked coins or a subset of them, you can decentralized lee. He made up a word at zero cost to you coordinate a rhark to undo the theft. What did he mean there?
speaker: A

text: So that's a really interesting question, and I want to unpack that a little bit. But first I want to address kind of what the conversation has been like around this topic for the past 24 hours or so. I think that Jeremy made an interesting suggestion, and as it just so happened, CZ was doing an AMA last night, and it was a previously scheduled AMA. They'd sent it out earlier and so someone asked him about this question. And I think that his CZ's willingness to even consider this idea is what has caused a lot of reaction over social media recently. And so to be very clear, binance is not pursuing this plan. They're not going to try and reorg the chain or roll back any transactions. CZ, just on the AMA, as he was asked the question, said, oh yeah, we would consider that. So bitcoin's immutability is not threatened right now. But that being said, it's a really interesting tactic because as it turns out, if you look at how the bitcoin blockchain works, each block rewards the miner with 12.5 bitcoins, and that is the security incentive for the block. Right? The reason to mine new bitcoins or mine new blocks is because you get 12.5 bitcoins per block, right? Now. And given that 7000 bitcoins were stolen in this hack, that's substantially more bitcoins that were stolen than the miners mine. And so what that basically means is if Binance committed either on chain somehow or off chain or through some other mechanism, and we can discuss some of the types of mechanisms if they committed to reimbursing the miners or rewarding the miners for mining a separate chain that did not include the transaction where the hackers stole the money. Then the economic incentive is possibly there for the miners to take that money from Binance and basically undo that transaction. Now, it's speculative because obviously undoing a transaction in this way would challenge the value proposition of bitcoin itself. And so maybe the miners wouldn't go for it. We don't know until someone.
speaker: C

text: So one technical point before we dive into all that, one part that I didn't understand about Jeremy's tweet was he said if you reveal your private keys for the hacked coin, so why would CZ need to do that?
speaker: A

text: It's only one way to do that. So what Jeremy was referring to more generically was create some sort of structure by which the miners who go back and try to rewrite history get rewarded. One way to do that is if CZ revealed the private key for the address that controlled those 7000 bitcoin, then if you were a miner who went back and remind that block where the bitcoin was stolen, you could replace the transaction that was in that block with a transaction that sent those bitcoin to you. And by revealing Binance's private key to everyone, that means that CZ would not need to coordinate with any miners or binance would not need to coordinate with any miners or call anyone or try and make this happen on their own. It would happen in a decentralized way because the incentive would exist for all of the miners that currently exist to go back and try and get those bitcoin for themselves rather than let the hacker have them.
speaker: C

text: Oh my God. Wow. Okay, this is incredibly, incredibly fascinating. So we're going to continue discussing the economics around this and incentives and stuff in a moment. But first, a quick word from our fabulous sponsors.
speaker: A

speaker: B

text: Back to my conversation with Tushar Jane of Multicoin Capital. All right, so, okay, they decided not to try this route, but let's just kind of entertain this idea. So do you think if they had tried that, they would have succeeded? So you said that that was one way to do it where they wouldn't need to persuade other people, but what was the other way? Because I did see some other people on Twitter talking about other methods and it did seem like those would be sort of more centralized.
speaker: A

text: Yeah, there are other methods to do mean, one that could be considered is just binance saying, hey, we will pay you. Take our word for it. Right, please go mine those blocks and we're a credible known entity in this space. And maybe some miners would take their word for it. Obviously there's a big trust assumption based in there. Or they could have sent a double spend transaction where Binance basically tries to double spend those bitcoin, but sends it into some sort of multi SIG wallet that is controlled by a number of prominent people in the industry. Who could publicly commit to rewarding the miners or even sign double spend transactions that send that bitcoin that was stolen to known mining pools and just tell them, like, hey, if you want to actually have this transaction be a valid transaction, you have to go back and rewind history and remind those blocks. And so because of the way that mining pools work, you know what some of their addresses are, and you could literally just say, we're going to try and sign transactions to double spend this money and give it to some of the biggest mining pools out there.
speaker: C

text: Wow. Yeah. So it could have been basically quite centralized in this. So I take Jeremy's suggestion where you could do it in a decentralized fashion, but in the other ways it was know if a few people decided, or rather if they got enough of the right people on board, then potentially they could have pushed this through. Is that right?
speaker: A

text: I would push back on that. I think it's somewhat correct. But there's very important nuance here, which is it's not about getting the right people on board, it's about getting the right economic incentives in place, because let me just zoom out and explain kind of the security of Bitcoin, right? The security of Bitcoin is all about miners having a larger incentive to mine on the current longest chain than to go back and try to remind an old block. And that's all based on how much the miners are earning. And so typically, people in the industry think that six block confirmations on Bitcoin is final, and they think that six block confirmations is final because at that point, it becomes very unlikely that any miners or mining pools would have the incentive to go back and try to redo history. However, when there are such large transactions at stake, when there's a transaction with 7000 Bitcoin at stake, well, now six blocks is just not final enough. And this is a trade off of probabilistic finality. With Bitcoin, there is not a single transaction that is actually final. Maybe the Genesis transaction, that's a more technical question. But no real transactions that you can think of are actually final. You can roll everything back. It's all probabilistic finality. Right? And so because of that, I think this is capturing a lot of cognitive dissonance within the community because they want to think of some of these transactions as final. But the larger the value of the transaction, the longer you need to wait for it to be actually final.
speaker: C

text: Okay, now, sorry, I just understood something, right? Because it's just about how much you could pay to have it rolled back based on the number of new Bitcoins being produced every ten minutes. Okay, correct. I just understood that. Right. And by the way, I just thought it was funny. You said pretty much only the Genesis block is final because that was more than ten years ago. But anyway, so here's the thing, though, that I find really fascinating. So both of us just said that if they had gotten the incentives right, which we're just saying right now, clearly they had the money to potentially get the incentives right, then they potentially could have succeeded in reorganizing the chain and sort of undoing the hacked transactions or at least diverting them in some fashion, which would reward the miners for doing that. But the thing is, they ultimately decided against. And so why do you think that is?
speaker: A

text: That's a really good question. I think they decided against it because they were worried that this would challenge the value proposition of Bitcoin. And CZ said, as know, CZ is one of the most transparent CEOs out there. It's amazing how transparent he is. And him revealing the entire thought process that went through Binance's executive leadership on thinking through this is a great case study that analysts like myself will use to study how major players in this industry would react to certain situations. So I really appreciate the transparency and the straightforwardness. Unlike some other exchanges who've been hacked in the past, leading to regulatory trouble, et cetera. So I think that transparency is really great.
speaker: C

text: Are you referring to anything that was in the news recently?
speaker: A

text: Maybe?
speaker: C

text: Sorry, it was just too funny. Anyway. Okay, keep going.
speaker: A

text: So I think that in the future, if exchanges are prepared for this and they have a plan ready to go to try and incentivize miners to do a block reorg within one or two or even six blocks of the hack transaction that would not only be more economically feasible, but it would also be more socially acceptable. Because reorgs happen all the time. That is not a strange thing. It's just the size of the reorg that matters. One block reorgs are totally normal. That happens all the time. Those are just uncled blocks. And that happens when two miners happen to both mine a valid block at the same time, or one mines a valid block without having seen the other one's valid block. And now all of the other miners that exist within the bitcoin ecosystem have a choice to make. They can either mine on top of miner a's block or on minor b's block, and that choice is pretty much random. They don't really have a major incentive to pick one versus the other unless there's some off chain coordination about that ownership, et cetera. Right. So even a two block reorg, not crazy, less likely for sure, but not crazy. And this is why most exchanges and other players in this industry want six block confirmations, because at that point it becomes extremely unlikely that a block reorg will happen. So I think if the next time there is a hack, if an exchange is ready to go with a plan that says, hey, we're going to try and get this reorgan within three blocks or something less than six, that would actually work.
speaker: C

text: Yeah, but see, the difference there is that in the examples that you gave of the reorgs that happen quite commonly, those are ones where they're sort of accidental and it kind of doesn't matter which one you build on right, for the next block. But in this case where they're intentionally creating a reorg and intentionally creating this competing chain and then trying to reverse transactions by getting people to build on their chain, I just still wonder, will people really treat it as just a run of the mill, kind of uncled block, as you described it?
speaker: A

text: Well, I don't know. Actually, that's a really good question. I think that if it's a smaller block reorg, then why does it matter what the intentions were? This is one of the things that attracts me to bitcoin, and that, I think, is one of the most valuable things about bitcoin, that bitcoin does not care what I think or what you think or what any of the people in the audience think. Bitcoin just is no one's opinions matter. The system is held together with game theory and economic incentives, and that is it and so maybe some people would be really?
speaker: C

text: But this is the thing but isn't that what we've been saying so far in this podcast? Which is that they could have crafted the economic incentives in a way where they could have gotten a reorg potentially pushed through, but they didn't do it. But why is that? Because this is not the first time I feel like I learned about some theory around how all this would play out. And then when we were presented with that situation, it didn't happen. Like with the 51% attack on Ethereum classic last fall. Before then, everyone was like, oh, the price would plummet. And obviously that didn't happen. So I just wonder here, is that the same thing where we think, like, I just feel like if the incentives actually were on the side of binance, then why didn't they do it? But why is that? I feel like there's something else at play.
speaker: A

text: You're asking the right question, but I think the incentives were not there for Binance. The reality is, while this hack was painful for them, it was fully covered by their insurance fund they could afford the loss and their business was not at risk there's no existential threat to Binance from this. Binance will continue to trade, it'll continue to be the world's top spot exchange and that's not going away and so it wasn't worth it for finance in this specific case to go after the reorg even to recover $40 million because the reputational damage would have been greater than $40 million. However, let's imagine a scenario in the future where some other exchange or some custodian gets hacked for a larger amount of bitcoin or something beyond what their insurance can handle and they actually have existential risk on the business. Well, then the incentives would be different and in that case I would expect them to try everything before letting their customers funds just be gone. Right, but here I just don't think the incentives existed for Binance to pursue this because they were able to cover this out of the insurance fund that is created specifically for this scenario.
speaker: C

text: Yeah and there potentially, I guess was the risk of creating a hard fork like causing some kind of schism in the community.
speaker: A

text: Yeah, it wouldn't have been a hard fork. That's one of the things that's different about this versus the Ethereum Dow instant I've seen a lot of comparisons about that in the community today right, because.
speaker: C

text: It wouldn't require the clients to update.
speaker: A

text: Is that why no one has to download and run new software? When you do a hard fork, you have to download and run new software. Something just outside of the system is changing. Whereas this would be within the system. You could continue to run the same bitcoin node that you are running today and nothing would change for you. You wouldn't notice. You would notice if there was a reorg, but you don't have to do anything. Whereas if there's a hard fork, you need to download new software.
speaker: C

text: Right? Okay. So one last question actually that I want to ask you about this topic is so I did see some people on Twitter kind of growing frankly about the superiority, I think, of like fast finality over probabilistic finality. So I wanted to ask, do you feel like this incident kind of says anything about the preference for some of the different blockchains or the different entities in the ecosystem for proof of work versus proof of stake chains?
speaker: A

text: That's another really good question. However, I think some ideas are being confused here. The idea of probabilistic finality versus quote unquote true finality is a separate idea from proof of stake or proof of work. You can implement, quote unquote true finality into proof of work chains. For example, there was discussions and I forget, maybe this actually happened on Bitcoin Cash, where they implemented checkpointing in order to protect against 51% attacks. And so checkpointing is the mechanism that is used to create true finality, whereas probabilistic finality is just a system where there is no checkpointing. And so if you get control of enough of the block production, whether that's proof of work or proof of stake, you could have the ability to roll back as far as you want.
speaker: C

text: So those two concepts are unrelated, but what is checkpointing?
speaker: A

text: So checkpointing is basically like you can say, after every ten blocks, we are going to take a snapshot of what the system is. And now this is final and there's no reorganing that away. This gets transmitted out to all the nodes, and all the nodes agree this is final. Right? Now, I have to just caveat this with I haven't seen many proof of work systems that implement checkpointing, and that is definitely more common in proof of stake systems. But there's nothing intrinsic about proof of work or proof of stake that says whether checkpointing should be allowed or not. It's a separate decision.
speaker: C

text: Okay, all right, well, thank you for clarifying that for me because I was watching those conversations and wondered kind of whether or not that showed some sort of future direction that all this would go. Okay, all right, well, this has been a truly fascinating discussion and thank you so much for coming on Unconfirmed.
speaker: A

text: Thank you for having me, Laura.
